Award.AwardTitle: Microstructural and Electrical Characterization of Novel Porous ZrO2-based NOx Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Exhaust gas sensors play a critical role in monitoring emissions and regulating engine operation in diesel trucks and cars. Recent emission standards for the United States places more stringent standards on nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel vehicles in order to further limit and reduce air pollutants. Current sensors are not capable of measuring nitrogen oxides at levels that will satisfy 2015 Tier 2, Bin 8 emission standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency. This shortcoming creates a need for diesel exhaust gas sensors with greater sensitivity and accuracy. This project focuses on gas sensors composed of a novel porous ceramic architecture. The research activities in this project are providing a fundamental understanding of how the sensor microstructure affects the electrical properties, kinetic reactions, and electrochemical response of the sensor. This knowledge is important as it has a direct impact on sensor sensitivity, selectivity and accuracy. This project provides research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students through participation in the data collection, analysis, and reporting of research results, which greatly contributes to their university education. The outreach activities range from laboratory research experiences to hands-on afterschool activities with elementary age children.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: New regulatory standards for diesel emissions have established more stringent thresholds for pollutant levels; thereby, creating a need for nitrogen oxide sensors with greater sensitivity, selectivity and accuracy. Current sensors are capable of measuring nitrogen oxide emissions at concentrations down to approximately 10 parts per million, which will not satisfy new standards. Novel porous electrolyte based gas sensors are a promising alternative to conventional diesel exhaust sensors. In this project, the electrical response of sensors with a novel porous zirconia electrolyte and dense perovskite sensing electrodes are being studied over a range of operating conditions. The aim is to acquire fundamental understanding of sensing behavior that is governed by the microstructural properties of the electrolyte and sensing electrode. The data generated is useful for determining kinetic reaction mechanisms, temperature dependence, and operating conditions effecting sensor sensitivity, selectivity and accuracy. The outreach activities range from laboratory research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, to hands-on afterschool activities with elementary age children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Automotive exhaust gas sensors play a critical role in monitoring emissions and communicating with the vehicle diagnostic system to regulate engine operation. Environmental regulations have largely been responsible for driving improvements in gasoline and diesel engines, as well as the use of cleaner fuels that have translated into lower pollutant levels. The US and other countries have strict emissions standards in order to limit and reduce air pollutants. Future standards are establishing more stringent thresholds for pollutant levels; thereby, creating a need for exhaust gas sensors that can detect lower levels of emissions. Diesel engines are more fuel efficient, in comparison to gasoline engines; however, the toxic nitric oxide emissions from diesel engines are substantially greater. To monitor diesel emissions, a nitric oxide sensor (i.e., NOx sensor) is included in the diesel exhaust after-treatment system. Current NOx sensors are capable of measuring nitric oxides at concentrations down to approximately 10 ppm, which will not satisfy future emission standards. In addition, improvements in diesel engine technology are also contributing to significant decreases in emissions. Thus, NOx sensors capable of greater sensitivity, selectivity, and accuracy are needed.

This project evaluated the sensing characteristics of NOx sensors composed of a novel architecture where the electrolyte was porous and accompanied by dense non-catalytic electrodes, as opposed to the conventional sensor architecture that utilizes a dense electrolyte with porous electrodes. The purpose of the project was to conduct fundamental studies on the relationships between the microstructure, composition and electrical properties of the sensor components. Understanding these relationships will provide the knowledge needed to support the advancement of NOx sensors. Key findings from this project are described below:

 

1)    The sensitivity and selectivity of porous electrolyte NOx sensors was enhanced by incorporating composite electrolyte materials that promoted ionic-conductivity and limited cross-sensitivity to water vapor in the exhaust.

2)    Dense non-catalytic sensing electrodes were found to contribute to the NOx sensing response and limit cross-sensitivity to several interfering gases (i.e., carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor). In addition, sensing electrodes composed of the rare earth oxide, (La,Sr)MnO3, along with the addition of 10% Au demonstrated high sensitivity to NOx at gas concentrations below 5 ppm. This exceeds the sensing capabilities of current commercial NOx sensors. These sensors is this research study demonstrated stable, reproducible performance.

3)    The potential for multi-gas (NO, NO2, CO, CO2 and hydrocarbons) sensing in these devices was demonstrated by measuring the frequency behavior of the sensor response over time. The ability to detect multiple gases using a single sensor was depended upon the type of sensing electrode used. Currently, complex sensor arrays and columns are used to detect multiple gases. The method explored in this project could substantially improve sensor reliability and result in lowering the costs associated with multi-gas detection for device used in various applications.

 

In addition to the research accomplishments, this project also contributed to: 1) the academic and professional development of several undergraduate and graduate students, 2) broadened the experimental laboratory skills of middle school science teachers, and 3) exposed several elementary students to hands-on science activities through the development of an after school science program at the local Boys and Girls Club in Ruston, LA.
